_metadata.description: Markers with known ancient DNA associations. Used to detect ancestral signals from prehistoric populations.
sources: David Reich Lab ancient DNA studies
Mathieson et al. 2015 - The genomic history of Europe
Haak et al. 2015 - Massive migration from the Steppe
Lazaridis et al. 2014 - Ancient human genomes suggest three ancestral populations
Prüfer et al. 2014 - The complete genome sequence of a Neanderthal

WHG.name: Western Hunter-Gatherers
WHG.description: Mesolithic foragers who inhabited Europe before farming. Dark skin, blue eyes.

EHG.name: Eastern Hunter-Gatherers
EHG.description: Hunter-gatherers from the steppe and forest zones east of the Baltic.

ANF.name: Anatolian Neolithic Farmers
ANF.description: First farmers who migrated from the Near East, bringing agriculture to Europe.

Yamnaya.name: Yamnaya/Steppe Pastoralists
Yamnaya.description: Bronze Age herders who massively impacted European genetics. Brought Indo-European languages.

Neanderthal.name: Neanderthal
Neanderthal.description: Archaic humans who interbred with modern humans leaving ~1-4% DNA in non-Africans.

Denisovan.name: Denisovan
Denisovan.description: Archaic humans related to Neanderthals. Up to 5% DNA in some Melanesian populations.

WHG.note: Blue eyes originated in WHG. Nearly all Mesolithic European hunter-gatherers had blue eyes.

EHG.note: Mixed - some blue, some brown eyes in eastern populations.

ANF.note: Brown eyes predominant in Neolithic farmers from Anatolia.

Yamnaya.note: Mixed eye colors in Steppe populations. Likely acquired from WHG admixture.

rs12913832.history: The blue eye mutation arose once in a single European ancestor ~6,000-10,000 years ago, during the Mesolithic. Hunter-gatherers had blue eyes but dark skin - a combination not seen in modern Europeans.

WHG.note: WHG had DARK SKIN despite living in Europe for 30,000+ years. This light skin allele was absent.

EHG.note: Some EHG carried the light skin allele, especially those with ANF admixture.

ANF.note: Neolithic farmers from Anatolia were already fixed for light skin.

rs1426654.history: Modern European light skin came from Neolithic farmers, NOT from adaptation in Europe. Hunter-gatherers were dark-skinned for 30,000+ years. The light skin allele swept through Europe only after ~5,000 BCE with farming.

WHG.note: Some WHG carried this light skin variant, but not fixed.

rs16891982.history: This second major European light-skin gene has a different history than SLC24A5. It was partially present in hunter-gatherers and increased through Bronze Age migrations.

WHG.note: No lactase persistence - could not digest milk as adults.

EHG.note: Lactase persistence absent in pre-pastoral populations.

ANF.note: SURPRISINGLY, early farmers could NOT digest milk! They kept animals for meat, not dairy.

Yamnaya.note: Only ~10-20% carried the allele initially. Despite herding, most Steppe people were lactose intolerant.

rs4988235.history: Lactase persistence only became common in the last 4,000 years - much later than domestication. It underwent one of the strongest selective sweeps in the human genome, going from <5% to >70% in Northern Europeans in just 100 generations.

rs3827760.trait: Hair thickness, shovel-shaped incisors, sweat glands

WHG.note: European hunter-gatherers did not have this East Asian variant.

ANF.note: Not present in Near Eastern farmers.

AncientEastAsian.note: Selected in East Asian populations, possibly for cold adaptation or other factors.

rs3827760.history: This variant underwent strong selection in East Asia ~30,000 years ago. It affects multiple traits: thick straight hair, shovel-shaped incisors (common in Native Americans and East Asians), and increased sweat gland density.

WHG.note: European hunter-gatherers susceptible to Plasmodium vivax malaria.

ANF.note: Near Eastern farmers did not have malaria resistance.

AncientAfrican.note: Fixed or near-fixed in sub-Saharan Africa for thousands of years.

rs2814778.history: The Duffy-null allele provides complete resistance to Plasmodium vivax malaria. It reached near-fixation in sub-Saharan Africa where malaria was endemic. This is one of the clearest examples of selection by infectious disease.

AncientEastAsian.note: Dry earwax variant highly selected in East Asian populations.

rs17822931.history: The dry earwax allele is nearly fixed in East Asian and Native American populations, suggesting strong selection ~40,000 years ago. It also reduces apocrine gland secretion (less body odor). The selective pressure is unknown - possibly cold adaptation or social selection.

WHG.note: Associated with blue eye color in hunter-gatherers.

rs4778241.history: Part of the OCA2/HERC2 eye color locus. Multiple variants in this region interact to produce blue, green, and brown eye colors.

rs1800407.history: This variant modifies eye color toward green/hazel. Combined with other OCA2/HERC2 variants, it contributes to the diversity of European eye colors.

Neanderthal.note: This haplotype is derived from Neanderthal introgression.

rs72921001.history: This region shows clear Neanderthal introgression and may affect pain sensitivity. Only present in populations with Neanderthal ancestry (non-Africans).

rs10774671.history: The Neanderthal version of OAS1 provides enhanced protection against RNA viruses. It was likely positively selected in modern humans after introgression.

rs35744605.history: TLR1 variants from Neanderthals affect how the innate immune system responds to bacteria. These variants are among the most strongly positively selected Neanderthal introgressions.

Neanderthal.note: Complex introgression history at this locus.

rs2066853.history: The AHR gene regulates the body's response to environmental toxins and is involved in detoxification. Neanderthal variants may reflect adaptation to different diets or environments.

Neanderthal.note: Neanderthal haplotype associated with lighter skin.

rs7277176.history: BNC2 is a major determinant of skin color and freckling. The high frequency of this Neanderthal variant in Europeans suggests strong positive selection for lighter skin at high latitudes.

rs1881227.history: This region contains one of the most well-characterized Neanderthal introgression haplotypes in modern Europeans.

rs1042602_anc.history: TYR variants affect melanin production. Selection at this locus contributed to European skin pigmentation adaptation.
